clips.what_happens_visually: Dwight explains why he won't let people into his survival bunker, with Kevin looking confused. Pam looks horrified.
clips.dialogue_hook: Kevin will be eaten. Pam will be taken slave. Jim will be made a warlord's jester. Meredith will do okay.
clips.meme_caption:
Sprint planning in a nutshell.
Stakeholder alignment is key.
clips.why_it_works: Exaggerated doomerism is funny, and the visual of Pam's reaction sells the absurdity.

clips.what_happens_visually: Jim is thinking hard, then Pam whispers a number in his ear and he nods.
clips.meme_caption:
Me estimating the timeline
for my side project.
clips.why_it_works: The visual of Pam whispering a ridiculous number is relatable to engineers who are constantly being asked for impossible timelines.

clips.what_happens_visually: Michael scratches his head aggressively and says 'Entourage' with a weird emphasis.
clips.meme_caption:
When the VC asks about
your 'inspiration'.
clips.why_it_works: The visual of Michael's exaggerated expression and the word 'Entourage' is perfect for calling out the superficiality of some startup inspirations.

clips.what_happens_visually: The Cookie Monster video is playing. Kevin looks at the camera and says 'This isn't funny'.
clips.dialogue_hook: This isn't funny. I don't talk like that.
clips.meme_caption:
When your AI avatar is racist.
Time to fine-tune the prompt.
clips.why_it_works: The visual of Kevin's serious expression is a great reaction to the absurdity of the Cookie Monster video, and it's relatable to the challenges of AI bias.

clips.what_happens_visually: The scene cuts to Jim, who is actually Steve, smiling and looking at the camera.
clips.dialogue_hook: Michael Scott, Manager. Hi, how are ya? Great.
clips.meme_caption:
When you gaslight your team
into thinking you're competent.
clips.why_it_works: The visual of the fake Jim, combined with the caption, is a funny way to call out the imposter syndrome that many founders experience.

clips.what_happens_visually: Pam is explaining that the new phone system allows people to call a salesperson directly. She wants a candy vending machine.
clips.dialogue_hook: I'd like to see a machine that puts out candy for everyone. Vending machine.
clips.meme_caption:
Me: "We need AI!"
Also me: "Can it dispense candy?"
clips.why_it_works: The visual of Pam's innocent expression, combined with the caption, is a relatable way to call out the sometimes-unrealistic expectations that people have for AI.

clips.what_happens_visually: Michael and Jim are giving a thumbs up, and Pam joins in.
clips.meme_caption:
When your team finally ships
a feature you don't understand.
clips.why_it_works: The visual of the three characters giving a thumbs up is a funny way to call out the sometimes-superficial support that VCs give to their portfolio companies.

clips.what_happens_visually: Dwight is dressed in a top hat and tails. He throws dirt at Phyllis and Kevin.
clips.dialogue_hook: I am dressed according to the schrute codes of mourning. My aunt Shirley has died.
clips.meme_caption:
When your startup pivots
but you're still wearing the old swag.
clips.why_it_works: The visual of Dwight's ridiculous outfit and the caption is a funny way to call out the sometimes-awkward transitions that startups go through.
